name: Interacting with AWS
description: Flashcards covering Interacting with AWS from AWS Cloud Technical Essentials Module 1

cards.front: What is an AWS API call?
cards.back: Any action you perform in AWS is an authenticated and authorized HTTP request to an AWS service endpoint.
cards.example: When you list EC2 instances using the console or CLI, you're making a DescribeInstances API call.
cards.subject: Interacting with AWS

cards.front: What are the three main ways to make AWS API calls?
cards.back: You can make API calls via the AWS Management Console, the AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs.
cards.example: I created an S3 bucket in the console, then listed its contents with the CLI and uploaded files via the Python SDK.
cards.subject: Interacting with AWS

cards.front: What is the AWS Management Console?
cards.back: A web-based graphical interface where you log in and click through services to create and manage AWS resources.
cards.example: I launched an EC2 instance by clicking through the EC2 dashboard in the console.
cards.subject: Interacting with AWS

cards.front: How does the Region selector in the AWS Console work?
cards.back: Changing the selector switches the console to send requests to services in a different geographic region, updating the URL subdomain accordingly.
cards.example: I switched from US East (Ohio) to EU (London) in the top bar to view resources in the London region.
cards.subject: Interacting with AWS

cards.front: What is the AWS Command Line Interface (CLI)?
cards.back: An open-source, unified tool that lets you issue AWS service commands programmatically from your terminal on Windows, Linux, or Mac.
cards.example: I ran `aws ec2 describe-instances` in my terminal to list all EC2 instances in my account.
cards.subject: Interacting with AWS

cards.front: How does the AWS CLI help with automation?
cards.back: You can script CLI commands and schedule them to run regularly, eliminating manual console work and adapting to dynamic environments.
cards.example: I set up a daily cron job that uses the AWS CLI to back up EC2 instance data.
cards.subject: Interacting with AWS

cards.back: Open-source language libraries maintained by AWS that let developers call AWS APIs directly from their application code.
cards.example: Our Python app uses boto3 to upload user-uploaded images to S3 automatically.
cards.subject: Interacting with AWS

cards.front: How do you list EC2 instances using the AWS SDK for Python (boto3)?
cards.back: Import boto3, create an EC2 client with `boto3.client('ec2')`, then call `describe_instances()`.
cards.example: In my script I wrote `ec2 = boto3.client('ec2'); response = ec2.describe_instances()` to get instance details.
cards.subject: Interacting with AWS
